DOC.HEAD: Crew Keeps Freighter Afloat
DOC.TEXT: A Greek freighter's 28-member crew worked to keep the 600-foot ship afloat while it headed slowly to Hawaii, the Coast Guard said. Sailors aboard the scrap-metal carrier Bulka, foundering about 800 miles northeast of Hawaii, used four pumps and were trying to get a fifth started in an effort to keep the ship from sinking, Coast Guard Petty Officer Dennis Hubbard said Friday night. The Bulka was listing 6 degrees to starboard and was down 40 feet at the bow, Hubbard said. Earlier Friday, the bow had been down only 15 feet. But after viewing videotape of the ship, Hubbard said, ``It didn't look as bad as it sounds.'' ``There's water over the bow, but the propeller is in the water,'' he said. The freighter, escorted by the tanker Chevron Colorado, was making 6 knots through low swells, Hubbard said. A Coast Guard cutter was to replace the tanker escort this morning. The Bulka's Athens-based owner, Bacolistas and Sons, sent two tugs from Honolulu to rendezvous with the freighter by Monday and tow it, Hubbard said. The Bulka had been headed for South Korea with a load of scrap metal, said Barry Arrett, captain of the Colorado.
